most_relevant_sentences: Technical details The power station is a run-of-river design which does not require a dam and therefore no need for a reservoir. Due to the water flow rates on this small river, only 1.65 megawatts could be extracted.

Both these islands lie just a few kilometres from Mozambique and are entirely surrounded by Mozambican territorial waters, but they belong to Malawi. The British originally claimed the entire Lake Nyasa/Lake Malawi, but in 1954 signed an agreement with Portugal, which recognized the centre of the lake as the boundary between their holdings and Mozambique, and making these islands an enclave.
His river steamer Ma Robert could not pass them to get further up the Shire; several members of his team died from disease and are buried in the area.

The peak was climbed in 2014 by an international team from the United Kingdom, Malawi and Lithuania, who measured it to be slightly higher than  Mafinga South, another peak on the watershed close by. The Luangwa River, one of Zambia's major river systems, rises in the Mafinga Hills on the western side of the ridge.

Mpatamanga HPP will differ from earlier hydro-power plants in Malawi, in that it will have a reservoir, which will allow Egenco to store water and allow for the expansion of Kapichira HPP.

Kholombidzo Dam, also Kholombidzo Hydroelectric Power Station is a planned  hydroelectric dam in Malawi. The scope of work involves construction of (a) a dam (b) a powerhouse (c) a substation (d) service roads.

Upon reaching northern Lake Malawi, the group divided, with one group moving south down the west bank of the lake to become the group known as the Chewa, while the other group, the ancestors of today's Nyanja, moved along the east side of the lake to the southern section of Malawi.
The lake is extremely shallow with an average depth of approximately eight feet, and during periods of dry weather the water level recedes and can even disappear.
